profileText: A Representative from Tennessee; born in Knox County, Tenn., August 31, 1794; completed preparatory studies; was graduated from Greeneville College; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1817 and commenced the practice of his profession in Knoxville, Tenn.; served in the Creek War in 1813; United States attorney for Tennessee in 1824; elected as a Jacksonian to the Twentieth and Twenty-first Congresses (March 4, 1827-March 3, 1831); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1830 to the Twenty-second Congress; moved to Jackson, Miss., in 1836 and to Goliad, Goliad County, Tex., in 1846; engaged in railroad building and management; member of the State People's convention, which met at Austin, Tex., in January 1861 and passed the ordinance of secession; died in Goliad, Tex., September 14, 1879; interment in Oak Hill Cemetery.

note.content: Election unsuccessfully contested by Thomas D. Arnold.

researchRecord.name: In the papers of Texas Governor Elisha Marshall Pease, 1853-1857, 1.88 cubic feet.
In the papers of Texas Governor Edward Clark, 1861, 1.19 cubic feet.
In the papers of Texas Governor Francis Richard Lubbock, 1861-1904, undated, 2.36 cubic feet.
1829-1830, 1958; 0.1 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: The collection is three letters written by Pryor Lea from Washington, DC, to his brother in Grainger County, TN, clippings published following Lea's death, a transcript of a eulogy read at this funeral, a postcard, and a biographical article published in 1958.
